1. Cyrillic alphabet: Unlike most Slavic languages that use the Latin alphabet, Russian uses the Cyrillic alphabet, which has 33 letters.

2. Pronunciation: Russian pronunciation is often considered difficult to master, with many unique sounds that are not found in other Slavic languages. For example, the "ы" sound is unique to Russian and is often described as a cross between "i" and "u."

3. Inflection: Russian is highly inflected, with six cases, three genders, and two numbers. This makes the language more complex than many other Slavic languages.

4. Vocabulary: Russian has a lot of vocabulary borrowed from other languages, especially French, German, and English. This makes it easier for speakers of these languages to learn Russian.

5. Word order: Russian has a very flexible word order, which allows speakers to emphasize different parts of a sentence. This is different from many other Slavic languages, which have more rigid word orders.

6. Verb aspect: Russian verbs have two aspects - perfective and imperfective - which indicate whether an action is completed or ongoing. This is unique to Russian and makes the language more complex than many other Slavic languages.

7. Stress: Russian has a complex system of stress, with stress patterns that change depending on the case, gender, and number of a noun. This is different from many other Slavic languages, which have simpler stress patterns.
